awd_titl_txt: Using Interactive Online Labs (IOLab) to provide Investigative Science Learning Environment (ISLE)-style labs at scale.
awd_abstract_narration:
A hands-on lab class is a key and unique element of the introductory physics experience, yet the implementation of effective labs can be both challenging and expensive. A particular problem is that approaches which work extremely well in small classes can be difficult to scale up to large enrollment courses. The goal of this project is to take a powerful and proven approach to labs, the Investigative Science Learning Environment (ISLE), and to combine it with an inexpensive wireless lab system developed at the University of Illinois, Interactive Online Labs (IOLab), to enable an innovative new approach to the lab component of any large introductory physics class. 

Recent pilot studies involving several hundred introductory physics students at the University of Illinois have demonstrated that moving away from the traditional highly structured concept-focused lab to a more unstructured approach that emphasizes experimental design, sense-making, and scientific communication, can actually improve a student's ability to interpret data and to reason scientifically, with no negative impact on conceptual understanding. These results are especially encouraging since the approach used in the pilot studies is inherently scalable and the IOLab system is inexpensive and readily available. The goal of this project is to assess the content and pedagogy that will be developed to provide similar design-based labs for all 3000 students taking introductory physics at the University of Illinois each semester. A key part of this effort will be to develop the tools and training needed to make this new approach accessible to instructors and teaching assistants that have little prior experience.

por.por_cntn:
A hands-on lab class is a key and unique element of the introductory physics experience, yet the implementation of effective labs can be both challenging and expensive. A particular problem is that approaches which work extremely well in small classes can be difficult to scale up to large enrollment courses.

The goal of this project was to take a powerful and proven approach to labs, the Investigative Science Learning Environment (ISLE), and to combine it with an inexpensive wireless lab system developed at the University of Illinois (IOLab) to enable an innovative new approach to the lab component of any large introductory physics class. During the course of this grant we migrated all introductory physics labs taught at the University of Illinois, taken by about 2,500 students per semester, to our new ISLE/IOLab pedagogy.  

This new introductory physics lab implementation is very different from the traditional approach that was used at the University of Illinois for the past 25 years. In the traditional labs, students followed explicit instructions and used equipment set up for them prior to the lab period to verify the physics concepts they learned about in lecture. The new labs use a much more authentic approach, modeled on actual physics research, in which students are focused on universal scientific skills like experimental design, quantifying and minimizing uncertainty, interpreting data, testing scientific claims, and communicating results.

The key components of the new labs can be summarized as follows:

  • All students have an IOLab device, typically rented from the manufacturer for about $50 per semester.
  • Before each lab, students work independently (at their own pace) on a Prelab activity using their own IOLab device. The prelab content is delivered and assessed online and is designed to provide familiarity with the physics concepts and the IOLab sensors relevant for the work that students will do in the upcoming lab. 
  • During the lab students work in groups and use their IOLab devices to address an experimental task of some kind. A typical task would be to design an experiment to test some claim (for example ?the period of a pendulum does not depend on its amplitude?).
  • Each group collaborates on a lab report that is turned in before the end of the lab period. The report submitted by each lab group determines the lab grade for all members of the group and is assessed using a rubric focused on scientific skills rather than on the specific experimental result.

Research to assess the new labs found that students prefer them to the traditional approach and that the new labs are more effective at helping students develop scientific skills and adaptive expertise. Two studies are summarized below:

  • Student attitudes about both lab formats were measured with Likert-scale surveys at the end of the semester. Compared to their peers in the traditional labs, students in the new labs perceived their experience as more fun and interesting, more helpful for learning experimental skills, and more relevant to their future work.
  • A two-component lab practical examination was given to students from both the new and the old lab formats to assess the differences in their scientific skills and big-picture thinking.
    • Analysis of written responses to a data analysis question revealed that students in the new lab were more perceptive about qualitative features in experimental data and more likely to incorporate their observations into their conclusions compared to their peers from the traditional lab.
    • Video analysis of students? progression through an experimental task showed groups from the new labs were both more observant and responsive to details that would impact their experiment. They were also more likely to discuss parts of their experiment with reference to the big picture of the task they were working on. For example, 75% of student groups from the new lab determined whether their result seemed reasonable, while 93.7% of student groups from the traditional lab either did not discuss or chose not to explain the meaning of their results.
